skill.name: llm-doc-writer
skill.description: Write token-efficient documentation for LLM context. Use when creating CLAUDE.md, README, technical docs, agent instructions, or any documentation consumed by AI assistants.
skill.summary: Write token-efficient documentation for LLM context. Use when creating CLAUDE.md, README, technical docs, agent instructions, or any documentation consumed by AI assistants.
skill.author: Aceek

security_audit.summary: All 55 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified markdown documentation syntax as security issues. Backticks are markdown code fences, not shell execution. RabbitMQ and JWT mentions are technology references, not weak crypto. The skill contains only documentation patterns and has no actual code execution, network calls, or cryptographic operations.

content.value_statement: Claude and other AI assistants waste tokens on verbose documentation. This skill teaches patterns to write dense, scannable docs that fit in context windows while preserving essential information.
actual_capabilities: Rewrite verbose prose into compact tables and bullet points
Convert paragraph descriptions into scannable command reference tables
Apply progressive disclosure to split large docs into main + detail files
Identify and remove filler words, hedging language, and redundant statements
Structure documentation for AI consumption with consistent format rules
limitations: Does not generate documentation from code or APIs automatically
Does not verify technical accuracy of documented information
Does not maintain documentation across versions or updates
Does not integrate with documentation tools or CI/CD pipelines

use_cases.title: Create your first CLAUDE.md
use_cases.description: Write a project README optimized for Claude Code. Include stack, commands, and architecture in under 500 tokens.

use_cases.title: Refactor existing documentation
use_cases.description: Transform verbose team documentation into token-efficient formats that fit better in Claude context windows.

use_cases.title: Build agent instruction sets
use_cases.description: Write clear, dense instructions for AI agents covering conventions, workflows, and project-specific patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Basic CLAUDE.md generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a CLAUDE.md for my [language/framework] project. Include: Project name, Stack (frontend, backend, DB), Commands (dev, test, build), Architecture (2-3 sentences), Conventions (3-5 rules). Use tables over prose. Keep under 500 tokens.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new project and need documentation for AI context

prompt_templates.title: Verbose to dense conversion
prompt_templates.prompt: Rewrite this documentation to be token-efficient. Convert prose to tables where possible. Remove filler words (basically, simply, just, please note that, keep in mind). Show code examples instead of explanations. Original text: [paste text]
prompt_templates.scenario: Reducing token count of existing documentation

prompt_templates.title: API documentation compact
prompt_templates.prompt: Document this API endpoint in compact format. Show the HTTP method and path, request schema with minimal fields, response schema, and status codes. Use code blocks for examples. No prose explanations.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating API documentation for AI context

prompt_templates.title: Multi-file progressive disclosure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a main CLAUDE.md (quick reference) and suggest file names for progressive disclosure sections. Main file should have: Stack, Commands table, Architecture diagram (text), Conventions list. Each detail file covers one topic deeply.
prompt_templates.scenario: Large projects needing documentation split across files

best_practices: Use tables for structured data like stacks, commands, and configurations instead of prose paragraphs
Apply progressive disclosure: keep main docs under 500 tokens with links to detailed files
Remove all filler words and hedging language before finalizing documentation
anti_patterns: Writing 'In this section we will...' or 'The following example shows...' - just show it directly
Including obvious information like 'This file contains...' when the filename already states this
Using multiple ways to say the same thing - pick one pattern and stick with it

faq.question: What is token-efficient documentation?
faq.answer: Token-efficient documentation conveys the same information using fewer tokens. AI models have context limits, so denser documentation lets you include more project knowledge within those limits.

faq.question: How does this differ from regular documentation?
faq.answer: Regular documentation targets human readers who benefit from narrative flow. AI documentation targets language models that process discrete chunks. Tables, bullet points, and code examples work better than paragraphs.

faq.question: What makes good AI documentation?
faq.answer: Good AI documentation is scannable, consistent, and dense. Use tables over prose, show examples over explanations, and remove all filler words. Structure information so the AI can quickly find what it needs.

faq.question: How long should CLAUDE.md be?
faq.answer: Keep the main CLAUDE.md under 500 tokens. For larger projects, use progressive disclosure with a quick reference file and separate detail files linked from the main doc.

faq.question: What information should I include in CLAUDE.md?
faq.answer: Include project name, tech stack, build/test/run commands, architecture overview, and project-specific conventions or rules. Skip information the AI can already access from the codebase.

faq.question: How do I handle complex projects?
faq.answer: Split complex documentation across multiple files. Use a main quick reference file for essential info and link to separate files for architecture details, API docs, and conventions.
